channel.title: Hacker News - English
channel.description: Hacker News articles summarized and translated to English

item.title: FreeMDU: Open-source Miele appliance diagnostic tools
item.description:
Next, you'll need to build a communication adapter to interface with your Miele device. Building custom tools If you want to develop your own software to communicate with Miele devices: Flash the home firmware in bridge mode onto your communication adapter and attach it to your device. org/licenses/MIT) at your option.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 5 Comments:

alias_neo:

I'm both pleased and disappointed.

I love reverse engineering efforts, and like to partake myself from time to time, so I'm very happy to see this; but, for a fraction of an infra-red-wave period I thought Miele had decided to be cool and open source some diagnostic tools for everyone to benefit.

If I'm not mistaken, they were the first (and only?) to open source 3d models for vacuum cleaner accessories.

amelius:

Wait, so with a strong enough IR led, someone could disrupt washing machines in their entire neighborhood?

wiz21c:

what we miss is a universal control computer to control those washing machines. It is very often that part that breaks and that is "so expensive that you'd better replace the whole machine".

NoiseBert69:

Time for some overclocking... 10k RPM.

Stellar Work!

Aurornis:

This is a great project. The blog post explaining how they reverse engineered everything is a good read, too:

https://medusalix.github.io/posts/miele-interface/

item.title: Replicate is joining Cloudflare
item.description:
Replicate Blog Replicate is joining Cloudflare Posted November 17, 2025 by bfirsh Big news: We’re joining Cloudflare. Cloudflare has built so many other parts of this operating system. This is why we’re joining Cloudflare.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 8 Comments:

philipwhiuk:

> Replicate’s going to carry on as a distinct brand

Uh huh

rvz:

A very smart move for Cloudflare and a huge missed opportunity for Render [0].

[0] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=42833414

coleca:

Great match up of technologies. Congrats to Ben and the team! I had the privilege of working with Replicate when I was at AWS, such a great team.

tasn:

Congrats Ben and team. Looking forward to seeing what you build with Cloudflare's backing!

aryanchaurasia:

why sell if they were doing good?

redwood:

Cloudflare is one of those companies similar to palantir where the valuation just makes you scratch your head. But bringing in AI to try and fill out the AI valuation makes some sense I suppose

echelon:

Acquisition or acquihire? I don't see a price tag, which seems to imply the latter?

How many players are there in this space? Replicate, RunPod, Modal, Northflank, FAL, ... Who are the big ones? It's pretty crowded, right?

FAL was smart. They ditched the "run any model" to focus on just image and video, and now they dominate that space. They raised a pretty substantial round recently. Though I don't think there's any moat and they'll soon face competition too.

What about these vs. the routers like "Open"Router?

simonw:

Congrats Ben and team!

I think this is Cloudflare's most notable acquisition yet? From Wikipedia it looks like they've previously mainly acquired smaller cybersecurity firms like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_1_Security

item.title: Geothermal energy might be the baseload revolution we've been looking for
item.description:
In some ways, the process of harnessing geothermal energy is simple. Thermal energy (steam) is translated into mechanical energy (the spinning turbine), which is translated into electrical energy (via the generator). The steam flow was such that it could produce ten times more energy than a regular well.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 2 Comments:

hodgehog11:

I've always been curious why a cost-effective widespread implementation of geothermal energy has never been considered a holy grail of energy production, at least not in the public debate. Much of the discussion is so focussed on nuclear fusion, which seems so much harder and less likely to be reliable.

toomuchtodo:

https://archive.today/CR2KL

item.title: Jeff Bezos Creates A.I. Startup Where He Will Be Co-Chief Executive
Ned: ImGui Text Editor with GL Shaders
item.description:
A retro-style text editor with GL shader effects. Ned also includes a terminal emulator and AI integration with OpenRouter support. The app also supports multi selection for selecting text with multiple cursors.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 4 Comments:

norman784:

From the video looks like it's already usable, with Lua or some other scripting language it could be a good alternative to vim or helix.

masfoobar:

I do find this an interesting project. I don't think it will serve my purpose as I already comfortable with mine chosen text editor.

I think many developers/programmers have already picked their poison - would anyone decide to use Ned?

Not suggesting it's wrong or a waste of time. Certainly not! I am always happy to see various alternatives out there in various sections of computing... even the likes of GNU Hurd still keeping itself going!

There has been projects where I've been very tempted to use IMGUI or others. It's just an easy/quick approach than building a website or commonly known GUI managers. (WPF, Qt, Gtk, etc)

The problem is - these projects are not about creating text editors, but some GUI Windows (or Windows) that solves problems with check boxes, buttons, and text areas. The problem is ALWAYS when the customers says "Ooh.. it would be good if we can do this!" which, for example, is supporting a Map.. like Gmaps.. which can be supported on the web or on traditional UIs easily.

Do I have the time to support a new feature? Unfortunately.. I dont! I end up using the tools or libraries that DO have these features available. In this example, I can just put together a website using Leafletjs.

Long story short.. as much as I would love to use an Immediate Mode UI to solve a problem... it sounds like a great idea... until it isn't.

reactordev:

The embed ned is awesome. Will make ImGui engine editors that much more robust. Fantastic.

I’m going to tinker with this.

stephc_int13:

Tried it on Windows on a powerful workstation. Felt sluggish. The framerate seems to be capped as 60Hz. My monitor is running at 240Hz. Removing the framerate limit could help.

item.title: GCC 16 considering changing default to C++20
